citation.biblCit: Population Research Laboratory, 2015, "Alberta Survey, 2014A", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10574, UAL Dataverse, V4

AuthEnty.affiliation: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

stdyInfo.abstract: The Population Research Laboratory (PRL) administered the 2014 Alberta Survey A. This survey of households across the province of Alberta continues to enable academic researchers, government departments, and non-profit organizations to explore a wide range of topics in a structured research framework and environment. Sponsorsâ€™ research questions are asked together with demographic questions in a telephone interview of Alberta households.

sumDscr.universe: The main feature of the sampling design was a two-stage selection process: first, based on a selection of households, and second, the selection of a respondent within each household. The Alberta Survey A aimed for a total sample size of 1,200 households across Alberta, with a minimum of 400 respondents in Metropolitan Edmonton, 400 in Metropolitan Calgary, and 400 from the remainder of the province (other Alberta). The target population are persons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, are living in a dwelling unit that could be contacted by direct dialing.

var.name: respnum$
var.labl: Respondent number

var.name: primary$
var.labl: Quota distribution

var.name: sex1
var.labl: Gender of respondent

var.name: aa1a
var.labl: How many times do you participate in STRENUOUS activity for more than 15 minutes during an average week?

var.name: aa1b
var.labl: What is the average duration of your participation in STRENUOUS activity in minutes per activity session?

catgry.labl: NA-No strenuous activity/NR or DK to AA1a

var.name: aa2a
var.labl: How many times do you participate in MODERATE activity for more than 15 minutes during an average week?

var.name: aa2b
var.labl: What is the average duration of your participation in MODERATE activity in MINUTES per activity session?

catgry.labl: NA-No moderate activity/NR or DK to AA2a

var.name: aa3a
var.labl: How many times do you participate in MILD ACTIVITY for more than 15 minutes during an average week?

var.name: aa3b
var.labl: What is the average duration of your participation in MILD ACTIVITY in MINUTES per activity session?

catgry.labl: NA-No mild activity/NR or DK to AA3a

var.name: aa4a
var.labl: 4a. During the last 7 days, on how many days did you walk as part of your work?

var.name: aa4b
var.labl: 4b. HOURS per DAY spent walking as part of your work on one of those days (last 7 days)?

catgry.labl: NA-No walking part of workday/NR or DK to AA4a
Reported only minutes in variable OWDMIN

var.name: owdmin
var.labl: 4b. MINUTES per DAY spent walking as part of your work on one of those days (last 7 days)?

catgry.labl: NA-No walking part of workday/NR or DK to AA4a
Reported only hours in variable AA4b

var.name: aa4bmin
var.labl: Derived Variable (aa4b*60+owdmin) Total minutes spent walking as part of your work on one of those days (last 7 days)?

catgry.labl: NA-No walking part of workday/NR or DK to a4a

catgry.labl: Reported only hours in variable AA5b
NA-No walking place to place/NR or DK to AA5a

var.name: aa5bmin

catgry.labl: NA-No walking place to place/NR or DK to a5a

catgry.labl: NA-No leisure walking/NR or DK to AA6a
Reported only hours in variable AA6b

var.labl: Derived Variable (aa6b*60+lwdmin) Total minutes spent walking in your leisure time on one or those days (last 7 days)?

var.name: aa16

var.name: aa17
var.labl: 17. It is my goal for the near future to participate in regular physical activity.

var.name: b1
var.labl: 1. Alberta can learn from China's economic success.

var.name: b2
var.labl: 2. The ability to speak Chinese will become more important to Albertans.

var.name: b3
var.labl: 3. China is a stable trading partner for Alberta.

var.name: b4
var.labl: 4. Alberta should promote energy exports to China.

var.name: b5
var.labl: 5. Chinese investment in Alberta in the form of partial ownership is acceptable.

var.name: b6
var.labl: 6. Chinese investment in Alberta in the form of full ownership is acceptable.

var.name: b7
var.labl: 7. Investment in Alberta's energy sector by a company owned and operated by the Chinese state (government) is acceptable.

var.name: b8
var.labl: 8. Alberta should take China's human rights record into consideration when conducting business in China.

var.name: b9
var.labl: 9. China will overtake the United States as the leading global power in the 21st century.

var.name: b10
var.labl: 10. China's growing economic strength poses a threat to Canada.

var.name: b11
var.labl: 11. Investment from China in Alberta should be more regulated than foreign investment from elsewhere.

var.name: b12
var.labl: 12. Increased Chinese investment in Alberta contributes to the provincial economy.

var.name: c1
var.labl: 1. 'Less-lethal' weapons such as Tasers should be made available to all police officers in Canada.

var.name: c2
var.labl: 2. Tasers are a safe policing or law enforcement tool.

var.name: c3
var.labl: 3. The use of weapons such as Tasers reduces my level of confidence in the police.

var.name: c4
var.labl: 4. Overall, I am satisfied with the official explanation of injuries and casualties in Taser-related incidents in Canada.

var.name: c5
var.labl: 5. The police in Canada are well-equipped to handle situations involving mentally ill suspects.
